column1: Crystal Lake is a city in McHenry County in the U.S. state of Illinois. Named after a lake 1.6 miles (2.6 km) southwest of the city's downtown
column2: Crystal Lake is 45 miles northwest of Chicago. The population was estimated at 39
column3: 829 in July 2019
column4: a 2.3% decrease from 2010. Crystal Lake is the largest city in McHenry County
column5: part of the Chicago metropolitan area.

column1: The City of Crystal Lake traces its origin to two separate communities which were established in the 1800s. Those communities were generally known as Nunda and Crystal Lake. In 1835
column2: Ziba S. Beardsley had come to the shores of the lake and commented that the "waters were as clear as crystal"
column3: thereby giving the lake its name. Ziba Beardsley continued south to Naperville. In February 1836
column4: the first white settlers
column5: Beman and Polly Crandall and six of their ten children
column6: came from New York State traveling to Crystal Lake in a covered wagon. Their original cabin was built in the vicinity of today's intersection of Virginia Street and Van Buren Street. Four of the Crandall children were born there. Najah Beardsley's family was the second to settle in the area; his grandson
column7: William Beardsley
column8: was the first white child born on the Crystal Lake prairie
column10: 1837.The town was first known as Crystal Ville. It was changed to Crystal Lake sometime before 1840. The area known today as downtown Crystal Lake was first called Dearborn and later
column12: from an area in New York where many settlers originated. The village of Dearborn was founded in the 1850s after an extension of railroads through the area. The first train station was built in 1856
column13: although it was pre-fabricated and shipped from Chicago on a flatcar. At that time
column14: the main business district for the village of Crystal Lake was located on Virginia Street
column15: about one mile (1.6 km) southwest of the railroad station. The railroad served to connect both the people and industries of Crystal Lake and Dearborn to Chicago and the rest of the country. Dearborn grew quickly due to this new rail connection.On October 7
column17: Dearborn's name was changed to Nunda. The village was platted in 1868 by local surveyor
column19: after whom a downtown street is now named. The village included the area now generally bounded by Illinois Route 176 on the north
column20: Crystal Lake Avenue on the south
column22: and Walkup Avenue on the west. Much of the land was originally owned by two early settlers
column23: Daniel Ellsworth and Simon S. Gates. The villages of Crystal Lake and Nunda were both incorporated in 1874. In 1908
column24: the name of the village of Nunda changed its name to North Crystal Lake. Several attempts were made to consolidate the two villages
column27: the village of North Crystal Lake was annexed to the Village of Crystal Lake in 1914
column28: and a consolidated city government was established.

column2: when the town of Crystal Lake was about 25 years old
column3: Charles S. Dole purchased over 1
column4: 000 acres (4.0 km2) of land overlooking the lake. It was his dream to construct an elaborate estate that would reflect his position as a successful businessman. He was an early member of the Chicago Board of Trade
column5: being associated with Armour
column6: Dole & Co. in Chicago. To carry out his plan
column7: he built a three-story mansion with adjoining gardens and stables. European craftsmen were imported to lay parquet floors
column8: fashion archways and carve interior wood work from black walnut trees grown on the property. As a final touch
column9: he brought in Italian artisans to build several marble fireplaces. According to Mr. Dole's obituary
column12: an enormous amount of money in those days.The estate was known as Lakeland Farm. Mr. Dole lived there with his wife Julia
column19: Sydney. Dole maintained the estate for over 30 years
column21: for his daughter's wedding in 1883 he built a spur line from the Chicago and Northwestern railway tracks almost to his doorstep. A canopied and carpeted walkway extended 750 feet (230 m) from the front door to the train enabling the guests to walk to the mansion for the ceremony and return to the train without concern for the weather. Notable wedding guests included Julian Rumsey (mayor of Chicago and Dole's first cousin) and Levi Leiter (first partner with Marshall Field).

column1: Mr. Dole's interests changed throughout the years. He laid out a half-mile racetrack on his property and purchased the finest horses that money could buy
column2: soon accumulating a string of horses that was the envy of northern Illinois. It is said that Dole loved to go up in his tower (currently closed off) and watch his horses run. When tired of the fad of his stable
column3: he disposed of his horses by holding an elaborate sale. The Doles lived in the mansion until the late 1890s when the property was sold to his son in law for $1.00.

column2: the property was owned and operated by several different ice companies. Ice was harvested from Crystal Lake and shipped by rail to nearby Chicago. The advent of refrigeration brought about the decline of the ice business. After laying vacant for several years
column3: the property was sold in 1922 to the Lake Development Company. Today the Dole Mansion is owned by the Lakeside Legacy
column4: along with Lakeside center
column5: which is the building connected to the Dole Mansion. Dole Mansion is located along the lake
column6: and there is a festival held on the grounds every year.

column1: Ringling Road is an east-west road which curves from Country Club Road back up to Lake Avenue. There are less than one dozen houses that claim a Ringling Road address; but those houses range from a small
column2: stone cottage to large
column3: imposing mansions. It is no mistake that Ringling Road provides the northern boundary for the Dole Mansion property. The road was named after Eliza "Lou" Ringling who
column4: as founder of the Lake Development Company
column5: purchased the Dole Mansion in 1922 and converted it into the first Crystal Lake Country Club. The transaction involved nearly a half million dollars and was one of the largest real estate deals handled in the area. The original Crystal Lake Country Club faltered in the stock market crash of 1929
column6: and Mrs. Ringling
column7: with her group of investors (the Lake Development Company) subdivided much of the large Dole estate into what is known as the Country Club Additions subdivision parts of which are in the neighboring village Lakewood

column1: The American Terra Cotta Tile and Ceramic Company was founded in 1881 just north of Crystal Lake
column2: Illinois. Most of the workers at the tile and ceramic works factory came from Crystal Lake
column3: The production consisted of drain tile
column4: brick and architectural items. In 1886 the Gates Pottery was established as a subsidiary with William D. Gates
column5: a Crystal Lake area native as its president. The company fabricated architectural glazed terra cotta that was used on buildings designed by architects Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright in the style of the Prairie School.  American Terra Cotta's company records show that architectural glazed terra cotta was used on many local buildings including Oak Manufacturing Company
column6: Teckler Building
column7: Cohn Store

column12: Pure Oil Research Lab and additions

column1: Gates used the facilities to experiment with clays and glazes in an effort to design a line of art pottery which led to the introduction of Teco pottery (from TErra COtta
column2: but pronounced locally as "Tea-co") in 1902. Many of the pottery pieces were designed by architects such as Frank Lloyd Wright Produced for only a few years
column3: this pottery exemplifies the Arts and Crafts Movement and today is highly sought after by art collectors. Teco pottery is in the collection of many museums.
during the Palm Sunday tornado outbreak
column4: a large and devastating tornado damaged or destroyed large portions of the city. Six people were killed by the tornado
column5: and a further 75 wounded. Damages in the city totaled over $1.5 million
column6: as 80 homes and a shopping center were completely destroyed. Disaster shelters were set up to house the homeless
column7: and then-governor of Illinois
column10: personally visited the city to view the damage.In the past 20 years

column1: Some challenges currently facing the city of Crystal Lake include a large and sudden increase in immigration
column2: and an inconvenient road system leading to frequently snarled traffic. However
column3: the overall quality of life and education in the city remains quite high. In addition
column4: a robust city park system and continued revitalization of the downtown area
column5: including a new city hall
column6: have continued to make Crystal Lake an attractive community for new residents. Another positive note for the city is that Crystal Lake is the city where the tradition of giving gold coins to the Salvation Army anonymously began in 1982.The Raue Center for the Arts
column7: in the downtown district
column8: has distinguished itself as a regional and national tourism draw.  The National Piano Conference has been held in the Raue Center since 2012.

column5: the largest single park in the district at 305 acres. Lippold Park has played host to the McHenry County Youth Sports Association Summer International 15-year-old Baseball Championships for the past 22 years
column6: drawing teams from across the United States and Puerto Rico as well as from Japan

column2: Crystal Lake has a total area of 18.957 square miles (49.10 km2)
column3: of which 18.35 square miles (47.53 km2) (or 96.8%) is land and 0.607 square miles (1.57 km2) (or 3.2%) is water.

column1: As the largest city in McHenry County
column2: Crystal Lake contains three high schools and has many separate neighborhoods.

column1: Starting from the north of the city
column2: the ten largest neighborhoods are easy to trace out. The first has no de facto name like the others
column3: but is referred to as "by Prairie Ridge
column4:
referring to the nearby high school of the same name. Houses in this neighborhood are large and widely spaced. The entire area lies just to the north of the city, from the downtown area to the adjacent community of Bull Valley. Some of the communities include Deer Wood, Covered Bridge Trails and Walk-up Woods. Next is downtown Crystal Lake, which rings Crystal Lake Central High School. Houses here range greatly in size and age, and it is the most diverse neighborhood in the city. Directly south of downtown Crystal Lake is the Coventry neighborhood, named for the major through street Coventry Lane. Students in the Coventry neighborhood attend either Central High School of Crystal Lake or Crystal Lake South High School. Oral tradition holds that Coventry was originally populated by pilots who fly out of O'Hare Airport. The neighborhood Burtons Bridge is located at the north-eastern side of Crystal Lake.
To the southwest of downtown Crystal Lake is the sprawling Four Colonies neighborhood, which covers nearly 2.5 sq mi (6.5 km2). Students from Four Colonies attend both Central and South High School. South of Four Colonies is The Villages neighborhood, which is named for its major thoroughfare, Village Road. An important feature of The Villages is Indian Prairie Elementary School, which is built on a large and steep series of hills that is a favorite sledding location during the snowy months. The residents attend South High School. A neighborhood Northeast of Four Colonies is Wedgewood. Wedgewood includes five ponds, and a forest that backs up to Huntley Road, with a paved walking path. Wedgewood has five brick entrance signs saying Wedgewood"
column5: and 3 prominent entrances; the front entrance on Huntley Road's intersection with Lakeview Drive
column6: the back entrance on Huntley Road's intersection with Boneset Drive
column7: and the side entrance on Country Club Road. Wedgewood consists of single family homes and multi-family dwellings such as townhouses. Wedgewood Drive circles the whole neighborhood
column8: and is a 1½-mile circle.Other neighborhoods in Crystal Lake ring the town's namesake lake
column11: and the Vista. These neighborhoods consist of many older homes built on the lake shore
column12: and vary greatly in size and style. Effectively a neighborhood and occupying the entire south shore of the lake is the independent Village of Lakewood
column13: historically a restricted community connected strongly to the Crystal Lake Country Club alongside it.

column1: There are also numerous smaller subdivisions found in various spots around the city.
The city's climate is much like that of its large neighboring city
column2: Chicago. The city experiences hot summers and cold winters
column3: with temperatures slightly more extreme than those of closer suburbs
column4: because rural land still surrounds the city. Due to the lack of the urban heat island effect
column5: Crystal Lake experiences colder nights and lower precipitation than recorded at Chicago. High temperatures are usually comparable to those in Chicago
column6: with only a few degrees difference on most days.

column1: The hottest month of the year is July
column2: when the average high temperature is approximately 86 °F (30 °C). Temperatures in July
column3: and in summer in general
column4: can frequently exceed 95 °F (35 °C)
column5: and occasionally exceed 100 °F (38 °C)
column6: although this does not happen each year. The coldest month of the year is January
column7: where the average high temperature is 23 °F (−5 °C). Overnight low temperatures are usually around 8 °F (−13 °C). In winter
column8: the low temperatures fall below 0 °F (−18 °C) on many (often as many as fifteen or twenty) occasions per year. Extremely cold nights may record temperatures as low as −20 °F (−29 °C) or lower
column9: but this is rare and does not happen each year.The wettest month of the year is August
column11: heavy downpours of rain. July is the second-wettest month of the year
column12: also mainly due to thunderstorms. However
column13: long dry spells can also occur at this time of year
column14: sometimes lasting weeks. The two driest months of the year are January and February
column15: where almost all of the precipitation falls as snow. In a typical year
column16: total precipitation is 37 inches (940 mm) with a winter snowfall total of 40 inches (1
column19: do occur and can accumulate large amounts of snow. In many years
column20: at least one storm will deliver 12 inches (300 mm) of snow in one day. Most snow-bearing systems are Alberta clippers
column21: while the more infrequent heavy snows are caused by Panhandle hooks.

column1: Among the city's sites of interest is the historic downtown district. The downtown district
column2: which recently has undergone a revitalization
column3: is home to many small specialty shops and businesses
column4: and is a local shopping district. Also located in the downtown district is the Raue Center for the Arts
column5: which seats 750 and performs plays and hosts concerts throughout the year. Raue Center has recently transformed itself into a regional destination spot by providing an in house professional theater company

column9: and Academy award winners. The Raue Center has received four MacArthur Grants and regularly receives National Endowment for the Arts support.   The city is also home to the Crystal Lake Strikers

column1: The economy of Crystal Lake is fairly decentralized
column2: as there is no central industry within the city. There are several large companies
column3: but none of them is a majority employer. The main economic activities in the city are retail
column4: dining
column5: and light industry. This includes small
column6: specialized
column7: local-owned shops and restaurants as well as broader-ranged national chains. There are several industrial parks in Crystal Lake
column9: independently-owned businesses which engage in various industries
column10: such as landscaping or automotive repair.

column1: The shopping center for most of Crystal Lake centers on "the strip"
column2: a long stretch of road that runs along what once used to be Crystal Pointe Mall but is now a series of strip malls. The strip is located on Route 14 between Route 31 and Dole Avenue. As the name suggests
column3: this area has mostly national chains. Another shopping area is the downtown district
column4: which is where some
column5: small independent stores are located. Because of parking challenges in the downtown area
column6: many thriving independent businesses can be found in convenient areas throughout the city where access for their customers is more centralized and parking is more abundant.If any particular industry could be called prevalent
column7: the city of Crystal Lake has several car dealerships
column8: and the south side of the city features several gravel quarries.

column1: The majority of these quarries are already exhausted
column2: and have been allowed to fill with water
column3: forming an area known as the Vulcan Lakes
column4: also stretching into Lake in the Hills and Algonquin. The two northernmost lakes are now known as Three Oaks Recreation Area. Recreational operations at this site started in Autumn
column6: and it has since become one of the most popular destinations in Crystal Lake.An approval for a hospital for Crystal Lake was given by the board in Springfield
column7: but has since met opposition. Illinois State law forbids the construction of new hospitals with less than 100 beds. The proposed Crystal Lake Hospital would hold 80-95 beds and be run by a Wisconsin corporation. Opposition from hospitals in Lake Barrington
column10: and Elgin were immediately voiced and it remains to be seen just when the hospital will be built.

column1: The city of Crystal Lake high schools are in a different school district than the middle schools and elementary schools. High schools in the city are run by Community High School District 155
column2: which runs four high schools
column3: including all three in the city of Crystal Lake. Crystal Lake Community Consolidated School District 47 runs all middle schools and elementary schools in the city of Crystal Lake. Prairie Grove Consolidated School District #46 also serves a portion of northeast Crystal Lake.

column1: There are five high schools which serve the city of Crystal Lake. The oldest
column2: Crystal Lake Central High School (Central for short)
column3: graduated its first class in 1924 and was known as Crystal Lake Community High School when it opened. It is located in the downtown area of the city
column4: and has an enrollment of approximately 1600. This school serves Crystal Lake and Lakewood
column5: as well as the far west side of Huntley and southwestern Woodstock. In response to pressures from increasing population
column6: Crystal Lake South High School (South for short)
column7: was opened in 1978. When it was completed
column8: the school was ridiculed for being remotely located and surrounded by corn fields. It now stands boxed in by suburban development. Prairie Ridge High School (often simply called PR) opened in the fall of 1997
column9: again due to increasing population pressure. The school stands on a hill off to the north of the city. The school serves mostly students who live in the 60012 and northern/eastern 60014 ZIP code areas of Crystal Lake
column13: and Burtons Bridge. They also serve some students who live in Cary
column15: McHenry and Bull Valley. A very small portion of far-eastern Crystal Lake is served by Cary-Grove High School
column16: which opened in 1961. It's located all the way in Cary
column18: and has an enrollment of approximately 1795. Students who live on the far east side of Crystal Lake attend Cary-Grove. The school also serves Cary
column22: and Oakwood Hills as well. Lastly for public schools a very small portion of western Crystal Lake is served by Woodstock High School. Also located in Crystal Lake is Faith Lutheran High School which serves the larger McHenry County area.
